I teach "Responsibility in Business" and "Big Data, Big Responsibilities" at Wharton, and I see a similar hunger among students to understand how they can do good while doing well.

1120022321626931200.text: We're finally waking up to the recognition that not only can one be a good capitalist while caring about things like inequality; one can be a much better and more successful capitalist in the long run.

1120022233479442432.text: If we focus only on the individual, inequality isn't a concern. And yet it's real. Ignoring it makes it worse, to the point where the whole system fails.

1120022024775057408.text: The root of today's American capitalism is the radical idea of libertarian economists such as James Buchanan that collectives (corporations, communities, governments) aren't real things; they are just assemblages of individuals. So the individual is all we need to focus on.

1120021695270572032.text: The trouble with today's American capitalism isn't wealth or technology; it's those things decoupled from responsibility. We've fallen in love with negative liberty - "freedom from" - and lost sight of what the Nobel Laureate Amartya Sen calls capabilities - "freedom to."

1120021561497374721.text: Capitalism is not the problem. The capitalism of Adam Smith, a moral philosopher, and the capitalism driven by what Max Weber called the Protestant Ethic, are very different from the capitalism of contemporary America.

1090660882974154752.text: The problem @mattyglesias identifies is more about losing the forest for the trees. Business schools teach methods. Sometimes focusing on methods obscures thinking about broader implications. Very different from teaching that social consequences don't matter.

1090659872004325377.text: Remember that today's MBA and law students are Millennials. As a general trend, they are more socially conscious than predecessors. And we've seen case after case of ruthless shareholder value maximization blowing up in companies' faces.

1090659422643339266.text: Even among students, I've noticed a strong swing in the 14+ years I've taught @wharton away from naïve versions of shareholder value maximization. Yes, they are capitalists, but they recognize there is more to think about than quarterly numbers.

1090658571480694785.text: Business schools teaching legal and ethical responsibility doesn't guarantee their graduates will always make good choices, of course. And business school faculty vary in their personal beliefs about social responsibility. It's wrong to say it's absent from what we teach.

1048634254815584257.text:

1048632953386008576.text: If you're not convinced by moral philosophy that decentralization isn't the ultimate good, think about it this way: The core evil you're battling isn't control or government, it's unrestrained power. Decentralized technological systems can produce it too.

1047318741451776002.text: This is already long and I’m only halfway through the post. So I’ll stop, other than to note my agreement with the last part. Governance is something we do, not something done to us. There are a range of outcomes, not just “success,” “failure,” and “death by centralization.”

1047318740495466496.text: Sometimes we can get there by piggybacking on existing reservoirs of trust (including the state). Sometimes by getting comfortable working with one another, instead of political signaling. The relationship of blockchains to other institutions isn’t just potential “capture.”

1047318739174285312.text: So legitimacy is ultimately about a richer set of procedural norms and fundamental values. It comes down to whether the losers accept the outcome as right and just and fair.

1047318738121498624.text: It creates the kinds of perverse incentives we see with the focus on “shareholder value maximization” to the exclusion of all else for corporations. In theory that shouldn’t mean “massively overpay CEOs with no connection to performance” but in practice it often does.

1047318736791846913.text: More to the point, other actors who don’t have the power to change the consensus may either be directly involved (as token holders or users of the platform) or indirectly affected through externalities. Cutting them out of the picture warps the process.

1047318735885914112.text: First off, governments have great influence over “common knowledge,” even for decentralized systems. But that’s another can of worms.

1047318734787018752.text: So this gets us to the next point, about the actors in blockchain governance. Node operators, devs, and trademark holders (or hodlers!) aren’t the only stakeholders. Perhaps they are the main actors who can establish “common knowledge," but again, that’s too narrow a framing.

1047318733893652480.text: The political philosopher John Rawls famously formulated justice (which is related to governance) in terms of the veil of ignorance. Not, “what do I want, and what do I think you want,” but “what rules would I want if I didn’t know which role I will play.”

1047318732761190406.text: E.g., “1 person, one vote” (or its tokenized equivalent) is more legitimate than “some animals are more equal than others.” Not because of our beliefs about others’ beliefs, but because of fundamental values.

1047318731775463424.text: So yes, governance is about processes, norms, and mechanisms, both formal and informal. Some of it is political, in the sense Vlad uses the term. But (apologies to Robin Hanson) everything in life isn’t signaling.

1047318730336886784.text: There are some coordination mechanisms that are effective, and generally accepted as such, but not legitimate. As a result, they won't achieve the benefits of trust as a "performance-enhancing drug".

1047318729237979137.text: Governance is more than consensus because it's about trust. As I discuss at length in The Blockchain and the New Architecture of Trust, trust is confident vulnerability. It's a leap of faith beyond what Nobel Laureate Oliver Williamson labeled "calculativeness".

1047318728239665154.text: This is where consensus and governance diverge. It ultimately doesn't matter why consensus happens, just that it does, reliably, and will into the future.

1047318727069454336.text: If the majority went along with the DAO fork because they believed Vitalik was a living god, and expected other node operators had the same view, an observer could still declare the process illegitimate.

1047318725920219137.text: If I say Donald Trump's election was not legitimate because he colluded with the Russians, it doesn't mean Americans won't act as though he's the President. The reverse is true, but that's different.

1047318724712312832.text: It's interesting Vlad defines legitimacy epistemically, as a form of "common knowledge." I can see why in the blockchain context, but it's misleading.

1047318723449839616.text: Finally had a chance to read @vladzamfir’s Blockchain Governance 101. If you haven’t, and you care about public blockchains, you should. https://medium.com/@Vlad_Zamfir/blockchain-governance-101-eea5201d7992 …. Comments follow.
